Noresco Energy Conservation Project/MSJC 2003

Wednesday, March 19th, 2008

FYI

http://www.noresco.com/site/content/CaseStudy_223.asp

“In early 2003, NORESCO completed a comprehensive energy conservation project at the MSJC campuses.”

Blog:

According to the above Case/Study link, posted at the Noresco website, MSJC entered into an agreement with Noresco in 2003. The project cost was $705,000 and provided the district with annual cost savings of $135,000. The question now, is why would the district propose another contract with this vendor, five years later in 2008, at a cost of $2,500,000 ($5,000,000 with interest costs over thirty (30) years)?

Who exactly is Noresco and who benefits most from the contract? The district or the vendor?

The BOT minutes for the year 2002/2003 do not disclose the agreement. Was it presented for BOT approval? If not, why not?

Share This

Board rejects $2,500,000 Noresco EMS agreement

Saturday, March 15th, 2008

FYI

Resolution 2007-08-134/”Approval of an Agreement with Noresco, LLP for an Energy Management System” failed on a 2-2 vote at the March 13, 2008, BOT meeting. Administration recommended the Board of Trustees to authorize the Vice President of Business Services to execute an agreement “subject to review and approval by the District’s legal counsel in an amount not to exceed $2,500,000.”

The $2,500,000 would be budgeted through the Board approved Lease Revenue Bond. Noresco was hired in November of 2007 to conduct an Investment Grade Audit at a cost of $56,000. That audit was not presented to the BOT for review prior to seeking authorization of the resolution. At the public hearing, Noresco made no presentation concerning the specific cost savings identified for the district. At the meeting, staff provided board members a one page overview of projected savings over fifteen years and a copy of the Board of Governors Energy and Sustainability Policy.

Acting Board Chair, Eugene Kadow stated that he “assumed” the district had done all necessary due diligence and would favor the agreement.

Motion failed 2-2 with Trustee Sparkman absent and Trustees McGargill/Motte voting “No” for lack of provided information.

Palomar College faculty, administration make progress in contract dispute/NCTimes

Saturday, March 15th, 2008

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2008/03/14/news/top_stories/22_10_563_13_08.txt

FYI

“Just last month, the union charged the district with unfair labor practices, saying district negotiators used delaying tactics, provided false financial projections and reneged on previously reached agreements. The district has disputed the accusations.”

“….It also includes a 4.53 percent cost-of-living adjustment granted by the state for 2007-08, retroactive to July 1, 2007. The parties also agreed to a cost-of-living adjustment for 2008-09, if the state allocates funds for that. If the district receives money from the state for reaching its enrollment growth target for 2007-08 and/or 2008-09, the administration has agreed to give the union a portion of that growth money.” Shannon Lienhart, co-president, Palomar Faculty Federation

Blog:

Negotiations at MSJC are on-going.

Palomar College updates grade-dispute policy/NCTimes

Wednesday, March 12th, 2008

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2008/03/12/news/top_stories/1_50_153_11_08.txt

“The updated policy, crafted by the Faculty Senate’s academic standards and policies committee, provides a step-by-step process that students should follow to first attempt to resolve the dispute informally, and then formally, if it reaches that level. Grade disputes previously fell under the broad area of student grievances, which occur when a student believes he or she has been subject to an unjust action.” Brent Gowen, President, Palomar Faculty Senate.

Blog:

The policy may better serve students in providing more timely resolution of grade disputes within clearly stated limitations.

Banning plans train underpass at Sunset Avenue to aid traffic flow/PE.com

Tuesday, March 11th, 2008

http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_B_btrain11.41cdd41.html#

“The city is still securing funding for the project. The underpass will cost $32 million to build. So far, the city has acquired $13.2 million for the project.”

“Banning Public Works Director would like to see construction start in 2009 and expects the project will take 13 to 14 months to complete.”

Blog:

The MSJC property in Banning is located at Sunset and Westward in Banning.
